title: Introductory Latin 1
description: A course designed for students beginning the study of Latin. Students will learn to memorize basic vocabulary and grammatical concepts and several patterns of declension and conjugation, will apply them to Latin sentences. Students also will learn to identify linguistic challenges and address them systematically. Instruction exposes students to Latin texts as soon as possible; for greater competence in reading Latin students are encouraged, upon completion of this course, to proceed to LAT102.

title: Intermediate Latin
description: This course is a continuation of LAT102. Students will extend and refine and practise their understanding of Latin grammar and complex sentences, and begin to read adapted and unadapted texts, with particular attention to vocabulary, grammar, and translation strategies. At the same time, students will develop their ability to articulate, analyze, and solve complex problems systematically. Students will complete the study of Latin grammar on the basis of the course book and thus be prepared to read and translate easier or adapted Latin authors in LAT202, and further studies.

title: Senior Studies in Latin: Selected Topics
description: A selection of material from one author or several authors or an investigation of selected themes, topics, or genres at the senior level. Topics and authors may include philosophy, letter writing, history, elegy, satire, Seneca, Pliny the Younger, Tacitus, Propertius, Petronius, and Juvenal.
requirementsDescription: Prereq: At least 0.5 unit in a 300-level LAT course

title: Advanced Readings in Latin: Prose
description: A selection of material from one author or several authors within the field of Latin prose. Topics and selections may include oratory and rhetoric, history, philosophy, Cicero, Quintilian, Caesar, Livy, and Apuleius.

title: Topics in Latin Language
description: This course will involve the reading of original material in Latin with a focus on the advanced study of the language itself, although topics may vary from single authors to literary genres to chronological periods.  This course is repeatable provided the topic is different.  Examples could include: Latin Palaeography; Augustan Poetry; Epic Poetry; Advanced Grammar, Reading, and Composition; Greek and Roman Identities in the Lyric Poetry of Horace; Latin Epigraphy; or Medieval Latin.

title: Introductory Latin for Graduate Students
description: This course covers the most basic vocabulary and grammatical concepts, including several declension and conjugation patterns typically in the fall, while focusing on the use of the cases, especially the Ablative, and the various tenses typically in the winter. After taking this course, students will be able to translate simple Latin sentences.
